Denver 2006.

nearly 10 years ago
Whoa, I thought this was from earlier this year (there is no event date in the video's description, so I just went with the YouTube post date).
there is a whole new level of 'exposure' to the topic, when you sit and see what many of the researchers have to offer. Instead of seeing them for a few minutes in an edited documentary, that you can get a different level of understanding of who they are, what they investigate, and what they've found.
I had not considered those aspects before.

My question - is why?
I've honestly never thought about going to a UFO convention.
I have nothing against conventions; I've just never had any interest going to one, UFO or otherwise (ex: Comic Con).
Honestly, how much new research or findings are there to hear about in the field of Ufology? Most of the "serious" UFO cases are decades old (http://www.mufon.com/famous-ufo-cases.html).
And of those, there is still...not very much evidence to present.
Even for some of the best cases (JAL 1628, Iran UFO case documented by the DIA), there is evidence that something weird happened, but no conclusive evidence that it was non-human technology.
One of the more recent "serious" UFO cases was the O'Hare airport UFO. That was as recent as 2006 (when most people had cell phones), but there still exists no solid photo?
And it seems some people are just making things up as things go along (see Jim "binary code" Penniston).
His "binary code revelations" BS has thrown up a massive red flag about the entire Rendlasham Forest incident.
And the Rendlasham Forest incident was one of the more "serious" UFO cases. No that makes me ask myself, who else involved in "serious" UFO cases is making things up?
Is Captain Teruchi of the JAL 1628 case (my, I guess, "favorite" UFO case) making things up as well?
So I guess the reason I don't go to UFO conventions in particular is the fact that I'm a UFO...agnostic.
I concede something may have happened (and this is a topic that makes me very curious, hence me reading/posting to this subreddit), but there is still no smoking gun.
I'm just a "weekend enthusiast".
PS: I do enjoy the work of "newish" researcher David Marler. In fact I think it's you at the beginning of this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W6wDaE6P0ok
Hindsight is always in 20/20. Hope things worked out, anyway.

My personal belief is that this may have been a military test involving two components: 1) A test of electronic warfare technology to find out if nukes can be remotely shut down, and 2) a military drone or other aviation technology "dressed up" as a flying saucer/orb to conceal the fact that the US has advanced electronic warfare technology.
What a beautiful shot!

I believe he's lying about the 'download'. Yeah, the amount of time that has passed seems to be the giveaway.
I believe something weird *may* have happened that night at Rendelshem, but I'm now very skeptical of the entire incident due to Penniston's recent claims.
Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice...
Absolutely!
Season 2 has been a bit of a bore but the supporting cast/characters are what keep me interested: Eichorst, Setrakaian, and Eldritch Palmer.

Decades after the incident, Jim 'revealed' that he downloaded binary code by touching the craft: http://www.therendleshamforestincident.com/The_Binary_Codes.html
I believe he's lying, and it has put a bad taste in my mouth regarding the whole incident.
If he's lying about this, then what else is he lying about?
This was one of the more..."serious" UFO cases, and I think it's taken a credibility hit.
And so I ask myself, if Jim Penniston is lying about this, how many of the other "serious" UFO cases have liars involved with them as well?

Probably one of the best documented UFO cases in history.
Ever since Jim Penniston's 'Binary Code revelation', I've become skeptical of even the most evidence-supported UFO cases.
As such, I've become somewhat disillusioned with the field of Ufology compared to my initial days of interest.
But whenever I read/learn something about JAL 1628, my interest gets piqued again.
I'll of course consider other options than UFO (unknown weather phenomenon; hologram weapon test by the military; electronic weapon test; a combination of those; pilots were drugged; etc), but I do believe something strange happened.
What on earth happened on that fateful flight? What I wouldn't give to be a fly on the wall (or in this case, cockpit window).

From another redditor:
"The shop owner, Jutaro Shiota, had a wife and two kids. They initially had to leave San Francisco, so they packed up and moved to Danuba, a small town outside of Fresno. Then the government sent them to an internment camp at Poston, Arizona.
A group of Quakers sponsored them, allowing the family to move to Cincinnati. Jutaro got drafted as a replacement for the famous 442 battalion, which fought in Europe.
After the war ended, they returned to San Francisco. One of the kids, Paul Shiota reopened the shop at 3131 Fillmore St and ran it for many years.
Source: http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/SHIOTA-Edna-Toshiko-2817527.php"
http://www.reddit.com/r/HistoryPorn/comments/3b7wsc/farewell_letter_of_a_japaneseorigin_businessman/csjtaqe

The Barcelona Supercomputing Center is in fact located in a former chapel, 'Torre Girona'.
Info: http://www.bsc.es/about-bsc/gallery/chapel-torre-girona
http://www.bsc.es/about-bsc/gallery/interior-torre-girona

A beautiful combination of technology and design.
"IBM System X iDataplex MareNostrum hosted by BSC in Barcelona, Spain.
MareNostrum is based on Intel Sandy Bridge EP processors 2,6 GHz (eightcore), 2 GB/core (32 GB/node) and around 500 GB of local disk acting as local /tmp. All compute nodes are interconnected through an Infiniband FDR10 network,with a non-blocking fat tree network topology and a peak performance of 1 Petaflop/s.
MareNostrum is also providing a rack with Intel MIC accelerators. The configuration per MIC node is:
2 Intel Xeon CPU E5-2670 @ 2.60GHz processors (8 cores/processor) 64 GB of RAM memory 2 Intel Xeon Phi 5110P"
Source: http://www.prace-ri.eu/prace-resources/

"This is a long exposure photo showing the paths of the multiple re-entry vehicles deployed by the missile. One Peacekeeper can hold up to 10 nuclear warheads, each independently targeted. Were the warheads armed with a nuclear payload, each would carry with it the explosive power of twenty-five Hiroshima-sized weapons which is equivalent to around 400 kilotons of TNT."
Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Peacekeeper-missile-testing.jpg
